Award.AwardTitle: Numerical Studies Of Walking Technicolor For LHC Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The world's most energetic particle accelerator, the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), has begun operations. This opens a new era of discovery in particle physics. A major justification for the LHC is to determine why the weak interaction, which causes many forms of radioactivity and controls the brightness of the sun, is so much weaker than the electromagnetic interaction. Ulitmately, this is because the photon, which induces electromagnetic interactions, is massless while the W and Z particles which induce weak interactions are very massive. But that begs the question of why the W and Z particles are so heavy. The standard explanation postulates that this is accomplished through electroweak symmetry breaking using the Higgs mechanism, which brings with it the famous but elusive Higgs elementary particle. However, the Higgs particle has not yet been observed and the Higgs mechanism has not been experimentally established. Therefore, to guide the interpretation of experimental results, it is important to study the theoretical structure and phenomenological predictions of alternative approaches. An appealing alternative is dynamical electroweak symmetry breaking caused by technicolor interactions. This project will use advanced theoretical techniques and a massive application of computing resources to learn how technicolor theories work and whether they can explain the experimental results that will be produced by the LHC in the next few years.

Project funding will also provide research opportunities and mentoring to support the development of a graduate student into an independent researcher. This funding also provides a unique opportunity for the student to become a member of the research collaboration, and to have access to resources at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, including researchers, super-computing, and specialized optimized software. At UC Davis, the High Energy Frontier Theory Initiative has a series of public lectures, several of which been related to LHC discovery potential. When there are actual discoveries, additional lectures will make those accessible to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The physics of the tiny and the vast are intertwined. Cosmology is concerned with the evolution of the universe on the largest scale, while particle physics seeks to discover the ultimate constituents of matter and their fundamental interactions at the shortest distances and at the highest energies. But one depends upon the other. The universe we see today is the natural evolution from the Big Bang when matter was far denser and its constituents were far hotter and more energetic than they now are. Thus the universe we can observe gives us information about the behavior of matter under conditions we cannot yet produce in accelerators. At the same time, what we do know about particle physics, the Standard Model, is an input for describing the evolution of the Universe at all but the very earliest times. 

Even without invoking theoretical arguments, we know that the Standard Model is incomplete. For example, it is unable to account for the observations of dark matter, dark energy, and the fact that the there is more matter than anti-matter in the universe. Within the Standard Model, the long predicted and recently discovered Higgs particle is an elementary particle with a central role. Theories that go beyond the Standard Model enlarge the theory so that it can explain more phenomena. One possibility are models in which the Higgs is a composite particle rather than an elementary particle. But theories of this type do not easily reveal their secrets to pencil and paper calculations. To make progress, we apply the power, indeed we stretch the power, of the largest supercomputers in the world. Similarly, we investigate the possibility that dark matter is composite rather than elementary.

Although expensive in terms of computing time, these simulations are still in an initial stage. Even so, they have provided encouraging indications that extensions of the Standard Model of this class have some of the properties that they need to be viable. In particular, a composite Higgs model may be able to consistently provide mass for the mediators of the weak interactions and also give the correct masses and patterns of electroweak interaction strengths to quarks and leptons. Composite dark matter can have both the abundance and weakness of interaction that are needed. This is just the beginning. We intend to press on in the search for a deeper and more unified understanding of matter and its interactions at shortest distances and its impacts on the evolution of the universe at the largest scales.
